TopicTitle: Planet Kerbin: A Field Guide to Life on the Kerbal's Homeworld

Articles.Content:
In KSP, Kerbin is pretty much a featureless green ball, with no life except the Kerbals, grasses, and the occasional tree or cactus. This is because the game is called Kerbal SPACE Program, and the devs wanted to encourage you to explore the great beyond, and not Kerbin. However, this is a blessing to nerds like me, who now have a whole world to work with, in a very literal sense. Therefore, I will set out to do what no one (I don't think) has gone out and done before: theorize life on Kerbin.

CHAPTER 1: THE KERBALS

Kerbin is a planet orbiting the star Kerbol, with a very unique property to it: life. It's just the right enough distance away to support liquid water on it's surface, and have very temperate climates pretty much globally, with the occasional dessert. One of the most unique and fairly bizarre inhabitants are the Kerbals. Kerbals are essentially the bare minimum of what can be considered intelligent life. They're able to construct governments and civilizations, and have even become a space fairing species, and most of this was probably achieved completely by accident.

Biology

Artist's (me) impression.

Kerbals have very large heads and eyes, with big arms and torsos and stubby little legs. This gives them more of a waddle than a walk. They have a very humanoid shape. It's unknown how fast Kerbals can reproduce, but their populations seem close to undepletable. If there was a mas extinction of Kerbin, their populations would recover, if not double, if given a century or two. In fact. their sheer numbers seems to be the only thing keeping them alive. Kerbals are known to be huge dunces, frequently getting into sticky situations. A large head might make you think that they have a large brain capicity, but what's really in there remains to be discovered. Their green color to their skin indicates that they may have evolved from plants, but have long since lost the ability to photosynthesize. The green color though could have also been evolved so that early Kerbals could hide from predators in Kerbin's open plains. Their ability to sweat means they are mammalian-esque with their biology. This is further backed up by their hair.

This entry into the field guide doesn't even cover a fraction of what lifeforms lie on Kerbin. In the next entry, we will look at creatures that are associated with Kerbals. Pets, livestock, and other such things.
